ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enhanced my understanding of the nexus between international affairs and energy.

This course enhanced my understanding of energy politics and its interaction with climate policy. In particular, we focused on different forms of the energy integral to the clean energy transition and the dynamics of that transition on the international stage. The course included a diverse range of assignments, including making a video on a new form of clean energy technology, writing a speech for the CEO of a company on their climate footprint mitigation efforts, and a simulation of an international climate negotiation. These assignments increased my awareness of the various perspectives and stakeholders in the clean energy transition and strengthened my discussion and writing skills.
Clean energy transition, finance, energy pathways

This class gave me a great deal of insight into the global energy space and the clean energy transition. Before this class I did not have that much knowledge of the topic but now I feel very well versed thanks to Ambassador Simons teachings. It is an excellent class to get a balanced and comprehensive view of all the current questions regarding energy and how it related to climate change.
overall of clean energy topics, opinions by experts in the field, great insights by graduate students who work in this career.
I was able to gain a broader, more global perspective on the energy transition

Learned greatly about the policy incentives and institutions that are currently affecting decision-making in climate change. Also learned about various clean energy technologies and frameworks for discussions in energy. Learned a lot about geographic-specific challenges like energy in Africa and the trade offs that policy makers confront on economy, price and externalities.
Understanding macro energy trends, distilling key points and takeaways, conducting international negotiations, delivering presentations.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The speakers were a highlight of the course. Professor Simmons routinely brought in global experts to lecture the class. I think the class will be more effective in person (outside of the professor's control).

This course is incredibly engaging and interesting without being burdensome. The readings are kept fairly minimal and the assignments are interesting and not too time-consuming. Classtime itself is more lecture-oriented with small pockets of student discussion. The professor has a lot of experience himself and brings in guest speakers almost every week, making each class unique and full of information.
Prof simons is great, learned a lot

This course is extremely well designed for learning and student engagement. The readings were informative and assigned well. The class was timed well and the visiting guests fit perfectly. One way that the class could improve is to increase the amount of student to student discussion and debate to make use of the wide perspectives and experiences of students.
Wish we would go more in-depth in more of the topics.

strengths: the attention the professor gave to the course, ability to teach a class

weaknesses: the level of difficulty was a bit low, would have been great to have a little more application of concepts

Strengths: Great speakers from the IEA and also a very well-structured curriculum. I liked the weekly updates that Professor Simons gave and also the transparency in midterm report and upcoming assignments.
Weaknesses: most readings were not necessarily referenced in class. I wish the breakout room - small group discussion was replicated in the in-person setting because that was really nice.
I enjoyed the breadth of energy topics we covered, but sometimes I wish we could have analyzed topics more deeply.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The small breakout rooms were effective. I also thought the open discussion sections helped to break up long lectures.

This course did an excellent job of facilitating lecture and discussion over Zoom. Particularly effective was the use of breakout rooms, which stimulated a great deal of debate and interesting ideas in a short amount of time.
The course was extremely well designed for high student engagement during the pandemic.
Breakout rooms were great. Getting to be in-person for a few classes was a highlight.
great inclusion of really prominent guest lecturers
I liked having small Zoom breakout groups to discuss questions and summarizing key points on Google slides, which were later posted on Canvas. I also thought that Zoom polls were used effectively.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. However, I would warn YSE student's that there is a lot of overlap with Climate Change Policy and Perspectives.

If you are interested in gaining a basic understanding of international energy politics and the mechanics of the clean energy transition, take this course! Ambassador Simons is a very engaging instructor and there are many opportunities to explore your personal interests within the subject material and assignments.
Yes, learn a lot great speakers great atmosphere

I would highly recommend this course to another student at Yale. Through this course I was able to learn a great deal and I have much better view of the clean energy transition. Further, Professor Simons is someone you want to met at Yale and is an excellent resource and mentor for your studies or career.
yes but I do think it is more geared to students who have not taken any clean energy courses before.
Yes, I would. I think it was an interesting course that a lot of love was poured into
I highly recommend this course as Prof Simons is very knowledgeable and you receive a great understanding in the policy framework and governing bodies that operate in the energy debate.

Yes, I thought the course that provided a broad overview of many global energy topics, so it's especially suited for those who are fairly new to this field. For someone who has several years of experience in the energy field, however, this course may not be as challenging.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We did include a few in-person lectures towards the end of the semester.
The class also had mini recorded case studies sometimes and the last few weeks class was held in-person with social distancing and the option to join remotely.
Also virtual seminar
We met a few times in person.
Live virtual lecture, in-person lecture

we were able to have several in-person classes towards the end of the semester as vaccination rates rose. It was wonderful to meet in person and I felt the level of engagement was much higher for the in-person classes
In-person lecture for last three weeks of class. Virtual seminar in all other sessions.
For the last few weeks, we had in-person lecture, which I appreciated because students were more engaged.
